lines: You have just found out that ${loverName} has a son from a previous marriage. Do you still want to continue with this episode?
Picky, picky! You'll have to go find someone else.

${loverName} has forgotten his wallet, and the two of you need to return to his place before going out on a date. While you are waiting for him to come down the stairs, you are greeted by his 15-year-old son, Greg, who is spending a few weeks
with his dad. He is a typical teen-ager, not overly friendly, and keeps his distance while watching you from the corner of his eye.
#BE FRIENDLY AND INITIATE A CONVERSATION WITH HIM
Your friendliness and good social skills make you an instant hit with Greg. Your conversation with him is light and easygoing. He becomes confident that you will not be a threat to him.
#SUGGEST THAT THE THREE OF YOU DO SOMETHING TOGETHER TONIGHT

${loverName} is thrilled that you would invite Greg along. The three of you have a marvelous time together. At one point during the evening, the three of you are talking together and Greg slips, accidentally calling you "Mom." How do you feel
It was only a slip. You should be flattered that you were able to make such a strong impression on the boy.

It is a nice feeling when a teen-ager can warm to an adult in such a short time. I guess his behavior shows that he really feels a void in his life. Your companionship, even for one evening, does a great deal for him.
Calm down. One date does not a wedding make. He was simply feeling comfortable with you and made an honest slip. Even Freud will tell you that sometimes a cigar is just a cigar!
${loverName} can see that you made a favorable impression on Greg, which he says is a difficult thing to do. This pleases him, and as a result, you have a romantic, relaxing evening.

It takes incredible patience and social skills to be able to converse with a suspicious adolescent. Unfortunately, you do not possess these. Every question you ask is met with the Universal Adolescent response, of "I dunno," or when he
is feeling really adventurous, "I guesso," which suggests that it was the wrong question to begin with. When ${loverName} returns, you can:
#SUGGEST THAT THE THREE OF YOU GO OUT TOGETHER
You must be a glutton for punishment. Fortunately, Greg declines the invitation. He is already late for the "Rabid Poodles" concert. ${loverName} doesn't mind; he would rather be alone with you.

It is probably a relief for both of you to be out of Greg's scrutiny. ${loverName} asks you to understand that his behavior is only a sign that he is disappointed that his parents are no longer together. The evening begins with a little tension,
Greg asks, "Where are you two guys goin'?" What do you tell him?
#SOMETHING SPECIFIC LIKE, "WE ARE GOING TO DINNER AND THEN TO A SHOW"
Greg turns to his father and says, "Aren't you going to feed her?"
#TRY TO PUT HIS MIND AT EASE
Few adults can compete with teenagers for long in the sarcasm department. The end result of the conversation is that Greg mumbles something nasty to you under his breath.

The two of you begin a shouting match.  Greg storms out of the room, and you are left explaining the story, which sounds immature. ${loverName} is angry that you took on a parenting role with his son when it was really none of your business.
You and ${loverName} have a miserable night

Perhaps you sense that this is Greg's way of alienating you. If the two of you fight, ${loverName} will have to choose sides. Your ability to let things go is a sign of strength. The night is not a total disaster. You and ${loverName} have an enjoyable
You probably sense that this is Greg's way of testing you. Perhaps he would enjoy doing something with the two of you tonight.
